heading.text: Team: Vince Bartle (vb344), Qiyu Yang (qy35), Youhan Yuan (yy435), Dubem Ogwulumba (dao52), Erik Ossner
The vision for this project is to let a user input their own database of relevant text sources and
produce a domain-speci�c novel search engine. This addresses the gap between something like Adobe
PDF reader which can conduct something like chapter �nding and ctrl+f, and the generality of
Google that works over the entire domain of what’s available on the internet. Simply, making it so
that browsing a PDF is less arduous.
Both prototypes are available on microgoogle.herokuapp.com/.

The information retrieval aspect uses cosine similarity to return the most similar pages of a PDF. The machine learning
aspect uses SVD on top of cosine similarity to sort pages by similarity. The social component tracks good and back
queries based on feedback given by users. The most major updates from the �rst prototype are primarily to do with
shifting the backend pdf parser such that we can derive paragraphs rather than just pages. This makes it so that our
results are more relevant to what the user might want. To access the �rst and second versions of the app you can select
from a drop down menu at the top of the app (version 1 and version 2).

The most visible changes are the now added social component of past queries made, the three versions of a search bar,
and displaying the result in a cleaner format, closer to what the initial PDF format is. These are all things brought up in

the feedback. There were also more aesthetic changes that have been implemented and this is still a work in progress:
things like switching from the matplotlib chart to something smaller and interactive, and moving the search bar to the
top.

One struggle we’ve faced is in implementing feedback around verbatim search and inclusion/exclusion search. One
approach we’ve considered, for example, would be to re-compute the TF-IDF matrix for cosine similarity based on the
window size of the query. E.g. if the query is “blood pressure” making a two word window. This recomputation step
though is very compute expensive. If a reviewer has a better or cleaner idea for how to implement
verbatim/inclusion/exclusion search please chime in or refer to some implementations you know of! Another feature
we’re looking into is adjusting the query such that we search for synonyms of a word in the query.

In addition to o�ering an empty search instead of a default search, we’re also handling cases where the similarity score
is not strong enough with a none found message. These two features combined make for a cleaner experience.

Provide 5 examples of inputs-outputs for which there is a signi�cant improvement from the �rst to the second
prototype, including screenshots. For each input, please provide a screenshot of both the �rst and second prototypes
for comparison. Ideally, you would use some of the examples you provided in P03, but that is not mandatory. With
each example, write a brief (1-2 sentence) description discussing why it is an improvement (or why there is none) and
what new feature of the prototype you believe lead to that improvement. If you cannot �nd examples where an
improvement is visible, explain in detail why you think that is the case.

Here you can see an increased similarity score, and a di�erent page; although it is still unclear what necessarily makes
this a better selection over the previous selection. One noteworthy di�erence is that the �rst example now begins from
the paragraph, not the page, as the version 1 o�ering shows. It is interesting that these two selections are of the same
content.

We added a new social aspect to the app where the past queries and results are stored as history. This allows users to
inform themselves of other users’ previous results and compare their questions.

We used a di�erent library to create a better plot for the graph. The new plot is resizable so it doesn’t take so much
space on the web page.

In the �rst prototype we used a binary representation for the query vector. In the second prototype we tried to improve
the cosine similarity results by adding idf score to the query vector. This resulted in a higher numerical value for
similarity scores (which is not normalized so it can be greater than 1). However, this did not seem to produce tangible
di�erences in rankings.

The result here still su�ers from the lack of verbatim search in the engine but re�ects the clarity of paragraph isolation
over page isolation.

Q: Brieﬂy explain the baseline method that is currently generating output. What information retrieval
and machine learning techniques (if any) are you using in your output? Does your method require any
special data manipulation or post-processing?

A: We’re preprocessing the data using various regex and NLTK tools. The preprocessing
method involves but is not limited to: removing non-alphabetic tokens, removing
stopwords, and stemming. We’re then extracting paragraphs using a github library called
pdfstructure. After which we use the scikitlearn tf-idf library to enable cosine similarity
on a query designated by the user, over the range of pages a user has designated, if not the
default range of pages and default query. The paragraph most similar to the query is
displayed with its corresponding similarity score and page number.
1. The follow example shows how a generalized query is not well handled. Especially
for the task of �nding something like ‘steps’.
2. This example shows how there is also not a great way to handle what should

otherwise be a straight forward topic, like ‘blood pressure’. The words pressure and
blood are found separately, but really we want something like how in Google you
can search for strict order of words.
3. This example shows where cosine similarity performs very well, where we are

looking for an entire matching phrase. We will need a way to re-weigh results like
this.

4. This example shows how cosine similarity performs slightly worse on shorter text.
We could try having a larger text box to encourage a user to write more about what
they’re looking for.
5. This example shows a total failure of the search, which we should handle more
The vision for this project is to let a user input their own database of relevant text sources and
produce a domain-speci�c novel search engine. This addresses the gap between something like Adobe
PDF reader which can conduct something like chapter �nding and ctrl+f, and the generality of
Google that works over the entire domain of what’s available on the internet. Simply, making it so
that browsing a PDF is less arduous.
The basic inputs provided by a user are: a PDF, and a query of some form. For example: upload
“Moses Medical Handbook for Nurses” and search “Steps for blood pressure”. At a processing level
we are starting with stripping the PDF down to it’s text and character level. The design of the output
is to be explored but we have narrowed down the following:
a. But also the evidence/context related.
b. The pages/locations of the most informative pieces.
We are primarily looking at the medical instruction domain, although it is possible to extend and
generalize this to any usage. For example, a patient is having an allergic reaction and the EMT on scene
needs to administer Epi-pen. However, they were never trained how to use one and need to �nd the
instructions of how to use it. The EMT uses our system and �nds the instructions for using an
Epi-pen and administers it to the patient.
Unlike most projects, our system is not trained on a latent database, but is instead provided by the
There is an information need associated with most instructional PDFs, that is unanswered by current
solutions such as Google and Adobe. The retrieval aspect itself will be extracted from the input
The social aspect we would like to provide through this project is based on the queries people have
made. Through this we can make something like Google Trends. We are also interested in asking “Was
this a good answer?” to inform our system and allow others to access what answers have been marked
as good. Along the same line we want to provide examples to new users based on past users queries, by
making use of our query tracking.
The system intends to allow for any arbitrary medical instruction manual of reasonable length that
the user can upload as a PDF, as long as it is in text format and not in scanned image format. An
example is a dental chair installation manual. It has 28 pages, and top 20 most frequent words with
their counts are plotted below as a histogram:
As we can see, the most frequent keywords such as “chair”, “headrest”, and “backrest” are closely
related to the central topic of this PDF, which is dental chair installation.
The distribution of the word counts are shown below as a histogram:
In this sample PDF, the vast majority of words occur in fewer than 10 instances. This is partly due to
the technical nature of the text such that the words used tend to be medical jargon; additionally, we
explicitly removed stop words and very short words (length < 2) during pre-processing.
One example is if a user wants to restructure a PDF based around a query. If a user’s query is: “how
often to take medication”, then the chapters about medication show up �rst, and beneath it the
decreasingly relevant chapters. Another example is if a user wanted speci�c steps for measuring blood
pressure, we’ve sketched this process below:
a. Meet one another and initial brainstorm.
b. Sketch out initial basic idea frontend and backend.
a. Final brainstorm for what initial use case will be.
b. Get a PDF to be uploaded and its text version displayed on the site.
a. Optional follow up to yesterday's sprint in case we ran out of time or into major bugs.
a. Display the PDF in a reorganized form based on a simple similarity measure based on a
b. Add a visual component like heatmaps for chapter similarities.
Enable radio buttons for data visualization.
a. First live prototype, a brief presentation and demo in class with a few live examples.
a. Accommodate a complex query like “Show me steps for blood pressure”.
b. Return a reconstructed PDF that a user can click through.
